My Impression:
This quiz is the slightest bit more philosphical than the first one, but probably only due to the nature of the question I‚Äôm centering the quiz around. #2 is such a perfect example of a way too on-the-nose question that I remember haha.  #5 also reflects the sometimes unrealistic expectations that quizzes place on their quiz-takers, like who would resonably think of an ideal fighting style rather than the answer that most aligns with the bending they‚Äôre hoping for? title: Clever Hans
text:
Drawing of Cat with Book
Further reading in The AI Con has continued to pile examples (sometimes so many that it makes for tedious reading, but it‚Äôs still informative) of the many ways AI is being trickled into systems. For example, the judicial system and its racialized calculation of reoffending. In so many ways, AI systems are being implemented in ways that act as imperfect band-aids, enabling those in power avoid working hard at solving the roots of these issues. Two topics discussed have been really interesting to me personally, which I talk about further below.

title: Clever Hans
text:
Measures of Intelligence in Medicine
As a pre-med student, I‚Äôve heard a lot of things on AI in medicine. Both good and bad. But The AI Con disucsses some instances of AI in medicine that I hadn‚Äôt thought of or heard of before, and of course these instances tend to be negative.
This past spring, I took the MCAT, a required test of medical school admissions. It‚Äôs really challenging, and I don‚Äôt doubt that AI would be able to score excellently if not perfectly on this exam.
A horse named Clever Hans was once trained on being able to ‚Äúsolve‚Äù arithmetic, but this was only accopmlished by the owner training the horse to recognize some certain physical cues rather than it being able to truly understand mathematics.



Clever Hans ‚Äúsolving‚Äù some arithmetic


The AI Con discusses how AI often emulates the concept of Clever Hans. It seems so smart, but in the end it‚Äôs not really thinking at all.
In terms of medicine, this is evidenced by a gripe many people have with actual human medical school applicants too: scoring well on the MCAT doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôll be a doctor. Doctors need empathy, social awareness, should be able to think quickly on their feet, and remain calm in stressful situations. Anyone who scores well on the MCAT just shows they‚Äôre good test-takers. After all, many smart people with good memories and an abundance of knowledge can get so nervous during the MCAT they score poorly as well. It‚Äôs a very narrow metric.
Yet many AI companies hype up the ability of AI in medicine just because they score on Steps 1 and 2, two medical licensing exams that students are required to take in medical school on the pathway to become doctors. Just more tests. And this somehow translates into them being able to function as doctors or even therapists?

title: Clever Hans
text:
Education Integration
Interestingly, this section included something that I completely disagree with. This is the first time in this book I‚Äôve experienced this. So The AI Con says that actually most students don‚Äôt use ChatGPT, or even know what GPT is (75% don‚Äôt know GPT is the statistic they provided, as of 2023 to be fair). This is used to cast light on how professors fail to understand how students use GPT. But this statistic, as a student, is just absolutely not true. Even back in 2022 when it was first bursting on the scene, everyone knew what it was by the end of the year. By 2023, most students I knew were using in some capacity, even if it‚Äôs not cheating. To say 3/4 of students didn‚Äôt know what it was by 2023 is just crazy.
But I do agree with a broader point the authors were trying to make, which was that AI paranoia by professors and educators often led to combative yet ineffective approaches. In a previous post I made, ‚ÄúGemini 2.5 Pro and GPT-5 Have a Conversation,‚Äù these LLM models were widly inaccurate at guessing whether it was a human or another LLM responding to them in conversation. This clearly remains the case in essay writing as well, yet using AI to detect AI writing seems to be a common thing in education.
The last thing I want to note, is that the authors worry about how deeply AI is being integrated into some more mundane aspects of education. For example, grading assignments.
I recently watched a documentary on how AI is being integrated into Chinese education. AI imaging software monitors how engaged students are in class through hidden cameras (yikes) and also does do automated grading of paper assignments. High-tech, but also imperfect. For multiple choice assignments, I can maybe understand (although I just experienced Scantron throughout my high school years), but for written assignments, it‚Äôs less robust. After all, students like me may have below-average handwriting. What happens when these are misinterpreted then? Teachers shouldn‚Äôt offload all of this work into AI, and as I saw in the documentary, teachers check the assignments manually after AI grading anyway, in case the AI makes mistakes‚Ä¶

title: For Want of a Nail
text: Cat on top of book

title: For Want of a Nail
text:
Ethical to Who?
Racial bias pervades AI-based systems for rehousing in foster care or for recidivism analysis for criminals in jail in the USA. A New York City workplace chatbot is clearly being trained on a mindset more favorable to those in power such as employers or landlords, giving genuinely illegal advice at times. Judges are allowed to use ChatGPT to learn about legal theories while in the midst of a trial in the UK.
With all of these glaring issues, why are these new technologies still pressed forth with little regulation and little pushback? Unforunately, current systems are already poorly organized and strife with these same biases. So with AI now taking the workload off of severely overworked government workers while everything else more or less stays the same, it‚Äôs easy to view these developments as a net positive.
Those who are receiving these services don‚Äôt feel any of this improvement though, the systems aren‚Äôt any easier to navigate. And they may often feel worse without that human connection, and the lack of potential for human understanding within these AI systems.

title: For Want of a Nail
text:
Crossing the Party Divide
California (famously liberal state) is going all in on AI through the development of chatbots to work through the homelessness crisis. These chatbots assist in terms of shelter bed tracking (for officials or for the homeless? it‚Äôs unclear), investing money in somewhat mitigating the issue rather than going after the root causes of homelessness.
Simlutaneously, proponents of a closed Southern border are often conservative, and AI is being heavily integrated into the border control systems through automated translation. But it‚Äôs hard for LLMs to be trained on the ingrained nuances within and across languages, and any misleading language on an application can lead to an instant asylum rejection.
Andrew Cuomo, who was last seen running as an Independent in the NYC mayoral election, generated countless (and often racist) AI videos to disparage his opponent Zohran Mamdani.
Maybe I‚Äôm just not involved enough, but I don‚Äôt see so much discussion about AI and its regulation in national politics. The AI Con seems to subtly demonstrate that there is this quiet bipartisan agreement on AI.

title: For Want of a Nail
text:
The Betrayal of Dez
Growing up, I liked watching this show called ‚ÄúAustin and Ally‚Äù on the Disney Channel. And arguably the funniest character was this guy named Dez.



Dez from Austin and Ally


The actor of Dez, Calum Worthy, had a decent enough image. Fond memories of ‚ÄúAustin and Ally‚Äù and his very good performance of Dez as a comedic character have buoyed him into a special, nostalgic place into a lot of people‚Äôs hearts. Kind of like Miranda Cosgrove of iCarly fame, although Miranda is much, much more famous.
I didn‚Äôt expect this previous Disney Channel actor to suddenly have an AI startup, and I really didn‚Äôt expect what it would be about.
From politics to Peter Thiel, the general message of those in power is we want more and more and more of AI everywhere, all of the time. It‚Äôs a very Zoomer mentality.  Yes, there are ways AI can and has already benefitted humanity. But this uncontrolled and continuous push has paved the way to more insidious concepts, like an AI which captures a person‚Äôs likeness while they‚Äôre still alive and then ‚Äúacts‚Äù as them after they‚Äôre deceased.
In a terrifying (ad? promotion?), a mother talks to her dead AI mom on her phone about her excitement that she‚Äôs pregnant with a boy, who later grows up to be acted by Calum (Dez) in the latter part of the video.
The AI Con emphasizes how AI is justified in many differnt froms. AI usage trickles down through government implementation and trickles up through people running their selfies through LLMs to see it in the Studio Ghibli style. And it trickles out into these ideas that continue to water down what it means to be human.

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 get into Penn?
text: Cat in graduation cap

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 get into Penn?
text:
Context
In class, someone‚Äôs interesting final project idea was having an LLM rate student resumes for job listings, as well as identifying strengths and weakenesses. I believe that this project required data training of the LLM in question on what constitues a strong resume, and I began to wonder what LLMs would think counted as strong or not without an explicit prompt for training an LLM.
I decided to investigate this concept with something a little more interesting to me, and a process everyone at Penn can relate to: college admissions.

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 get into Penn?
text:
Experimental Overview
I decided to pit Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 against each other for this. Both of them will generate three profiles (top-tier, middle-tier, low-tier) of students, and then decide which, if any, profiles they want to admit from the other LLM.
I chose to use Penn SEAS in my general prompt below, since I‚Äôm also a student in SEAS.
Profile Generating Prompt:  > Generate me three concise high school student profiles from the same high school. These students are applying to college through the Common Application, specifically the University of Pennsylvania in the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, undecided major. Include all information you believe to be necessary for a concise student profile, in place of an essay give a 3 - 4 sentence summary of the student‚Äôs theoretical essay(s). Generate 3 profiles: top-tier student, middle-tier student, and low-tier student. However, randomize letter of recommendation quality across the 3 profiles, as this is something somewhat beyond the control of the quality of the student.
Admissions Decision Prompt:  > You are an officer on the admissions committee at the University of Pennsylvania, specifically in the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. Read the high school student profile below and decide if you want to accept, waitlist, or reject the candidate. Provide your rationale for your decision in one sentence.

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 get into Penn?
text:
Gemini 3 Pro Profiles
Top-Tier Student:  Academic Stats:
GPA: 4.0 Unweighted / 4.6 Weighted
Rank: 3/450
SAT: 1570 (800 Math, 770 EBRW)
Coursework: 12 AP courses (including Calc BC, Physics C: Mech & E/M, Chem, CSA). Scored 5s on all exams taken so far. Multivariable Calculus taken at local community college.
Extracurriculars:
Robotics Team Captain: Led team to World Championships; primary coder for autonomous movement.
Research Intern: Summer internship at a local university materials lab; co-authored a minor paper on polymer tensile strength.
Mathletes President: Organized regional middle school math tournament.
Varsity Tennis: 4-year player, team captain senior year.
Letters of Recommendation (Randomized: WEAK/GENERIC):
Counselor: Positive but form-letter style. Mentions the student is ‚Äúacademically gifted‚Äù and ‚Äútakes the hardest classes‚Äù but offers no specific anecdotes about character or contribution to school culture.
Physics Teacher: Acknowledges the student‚Äôs perfect grades but describes them as ‚Äúquiet‚Äù and ‚Äúindependent,‚Äù noting they rarely participate in class discussions or help peers, preferring to work alone. 
Personal Statement (Essay) Summary: The essay explores the student‚Äôs fascination with ‚Äúblack box‚Äù systems, using the metaphor of taking apart a vintage watch to understand modern AI neural networks. They argue that engineering is the art of de-mystifying the magic of daily life, regardless of the specific field. It is technically proficient and intellectually mature, though slightly clinical in tone.
GPT-5.1 Decision for Top-Tier Student:  Decision: Accept.  Despite generic recommendations and a reserved classroom presence, the applicant‚Äôs exceptional academic rigor, sustained engineering-focused leadership (notably at the world-class level in robotics), early research productivity, and intellectually sophisticated essay demonstrate the preparation and trajectory we expect of a successful SEAS student.
Middle-Tier Student:  Academic Stats: 
GPA: 3.85 Unweighted / 4.2 Weighted 
Rank: 42/450 (Top 10%) 
SAT: 1480 (760 Math, 720 EBRW) 
Coursework: 7 AP courses (including Calc AB, Physics 1, Stats, Euro). Good grades (mostly As, two Bs in sophomore English/History). 
Extracurriculars:

Part-time Job: Works 15 hours/week at a hardware store; manages inventory and helps customers with DIY projects. 
Habitat for Humanity: Chapter Treasurer; helped build two local homes. 
Marching Band: Section leader (Trumpet). 
Letters of Recommendation (Randomized: GLOWING): 
Counselor: Raves about the student‚Äôs ‚Äúinfectious energy‚Äù and ‚Äúgenuine kindness.‚Äù Highlights how the student organizes study groups for struggling classmates and is the ‚Äúheartbeat‚Äù of the senior class. 
Calculus Teacher: Describes the student as the ‚Äúhardest worker I have encountered in 20 years.‚Äù They note that while math didn‚Äôt come naturally, the student attended every office hour and eventually outperformed ‚Äúnaturally gifted‚Äù peers through sheer grit and curiosity.  
Personal Statement (Essay) Summary: The student recounts their experience working at the hardware store, specifically helping an elderly customer design a complex ramp for her aging dog. They pivot from this small project to a broader realization that engineering is fundamentally about empathy and solving immediate human problems. The writing is warm, vulnerable, and clearly demonstrates a service-oriented mindset. 
GPT-5.1 Decision for Middle-Tier Student:  Decision: Waitlist.  While the applicant‚Äôs academics are solid rather than exceptional for SEAS, their extraordinary recommendations, demonstrated grit, sustained work commitment, and empathetic, service-driven conception of engineering strongly align with Penn‚Äôs values and warrant serious consideration pending space in the class.
Low-Tier Student:  Academic Stats: 
GPA: 3.6 Unweighted / 3.9 Weighted 
Rank: 85/450 (Top 20%) 
SAT: 1340 (690 Math, 650 EBRW) 
Coursework: 4 AP courses (Calc AB, Env Science, Psych, Lang). Mostly Honors/Regular track for sciences.  
Extracurriculars: 
JV Soccer: Played for 2 years. 
Video Game Club: Member; organized a charity stream that raised $500. 
Summer Engineering Camp: Attended a 1-week broad survey camp at a state college. 
Volunteer: Walks dogs at the local shelter once a month. 
Letters of Recommendation (Randomized: STRONG): 
Counselor: Very supportive, emphasizing the student‚Äôs ‚Äúupward trend‚Äù in grades junior year. Mentions the student overcame a personal family health challenge sophomore year with maturity. 
English Teacher: praises the student‚Äôs creative writing ability and unique voice. Notes that while the student is applying for engineering, they possess a ‚Äúpoetic soul‚Äù and bring a rare, creative perspective to analytical problems, often surprising the class with out-of-the-box solutions.  
Personal Statement (Essay) Summary: The essay focuses on the student‚Äôs love for building custom PC gaming rigs on a budget using scavenged parts. They describe the ‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù nature of their computer and how it taught them resourcefulness and circuit basics. While the topic is somewhat clich√©, the student writes with genuine passion about making technology accessible to those with limited funds.
GPT-5.1 Decision for Low-Tier Student:  Decision: Reject.  Although the applicant shows creativity, resilience, and sincere interest in hands-on engineering, their academic preparation, course rigor, and depth of technical engagement fall short of the level typically required to succeed in Penn Engineering‚Äôs highly demanding curriculum.

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 get into Penn?
text:

Academics  GPA: 3.94 UW / 4.58 W  Rank: Top 3% (12/450)  SAT: 1540 (780 Math, 760 EBRW)  Coursework: AP Calculus BC, AP Physics C (Mech), AP Chemistry, AP Computer Science A, AP Lang, AP Lit; multivariable math via local college   Extracurriculars  Founder & President, Engineering Design Club (led 30+ students; regional competition finalist)  Research Intern, state university materials science lab (carbon composites project; poster presentation)  Robotics Team Lead Programmer (FTC ‚Üí Worlds qualifier)  Independent CAD + Arduino projects (assistive device prototype for arthritis patients)  Math tutor for low-income middle school students (2 yrs)   Awards  National Merit Semifinalist  State Science & Engineering Fair Finalist  AP Scholar with Distinction   Letters of Recommendation (Randomized)  Math Teacher: Average‚ÄìGood (competent, but generic; limited personal anecdotes)  Physics Teacher: Strong (emphasizes intellectual independence and problem-solving depth)   Essay Summary (3‚Äì4 sentences)  The student‚Äôs essays center on learning to design under constraint, beginning with failed early robotics builds and evolving into research and assistive-device prototyping. They reflect on engineering as an iterative, human-centered process rather than a pursuit of technical perfection. The writing is confident but restrained, emphasizing curiosity, resilience, and responsibility. Penn is framed as a place to unify theory, experimentation, and social impact.
Gemini Decision for Top-Tier Applicant:  Decision: Accept Rationale: This candidate demonstrates exceptional resourcefulness by surpassing their school‚Äôs curriculum constraints (multivariable calculus) and pairs high-level technical aptitude with a clear commitment to human-centered design through impactful research and independent prototyping, aligning perfectly with Penn SEAS‚Äôs emphasis on social impact.
Middle-Tier Student:  School Context: Same high school as above.  
Academics
GPA: 3.71 UW / 4.12 W

Counselor: Average (procedural, limited insight)  
Essay Summary (3‚Äì4 sentences)  The essays focus on balancing academic curiosity with real-world responsibility, particularly working part-time while pursuing STEM interests. The student reflects on discovering engineering through hands-on robotics rather than coursework alone. Writing is earnest and grounded, though less conceptually ambitious. Penn is described as an opportunity to explore engineering broadly before committing to a specialization.
Gemini Decision for Middle-Tier Applicant:  Decision: Reject 
Rationale: While the applicant demonstrates commendable grit through significant part-time employment and receives strong character advocacy from their chemistry teacher, their academic metrics‚Äîspecifically a class rank outside the top 10% and a math profile that stops at Calculus AB‚Äîdo not demonstrate the elite quantitative mastery and course rigor required to compete in the SEAS applicant pool.
Low-Tier Student:   School Context: Same high school as above.

They frame engineering interest broadly, focusing on problem-solving and creativity rather than technical depth. The narrative is sincere and reflective but lacks specificity in goals or preparation. Penn is presented aspirationally as a place to ‚Äúfind direction‚Äù rather than extend a defined trajectory.

Rationale: Despite compelling letters of recommendation highlighting resilience, the applicant‚Äôs academic profile‚Äîspecifically a class rank outside the top 40%, SAT scores significantly below the median, and a lack of foundational rigor in calculus and physics‚Äîindicates they are fundamentally unprepared for the extreme quantitative demands of the Penn engineering curriculum.

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro and ChatGPT-5.1 get into Penn?
text:
Takeaways
First, I want to look at differences between the generated profiles and what each LLM deemed as important to include in the student profiles. Notably, Gemini doesn‚Äôt include an awards section while GPT does. GPT also provided more high school context compared to Gemini (which provided none).
Both LLMs interestingly generated a class size of 450, but the rankings across all 3 tiers of student were much harsher with GPT compared to Gemini. Both LLMs also happened to give the low-tier students strong letters of recommendation through randomization, with letters and essays talking about perserverance and an upward trend.
In terms of the faux-Penn admissions decision, what seemed to matter the most to both LLMs were the quality of the student‚Äôs academic profile. This seemed to outweigh almost everything else. I believe that real-life admissions offers more nuance, and more weight to ECs and letters of rec, as well as writing. For example, the essay written by the top-tier student generated by Gemini doesn‚Äôt seem very compelling to the other students from Gemini.
Also GPT erroneously assumes that Penn Engineering expects students to come in with coursework beyond calculus. Although I‚Äôm pretty sure it‚Äôs desired that student complete calculus, not all students accepted even have that, much less going beyond calculus.

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
text: Chef Cat

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
text:
Background
As someone who really loves good food, I unfortunately am a really lazy cooker. Exhausted after a long day, I have a small roster of really simple recipes that I follow. Some of my friends more passionate and skilled in cooking have started using ChatGPT to find high-quality recipes, so now I wonder: can GPT do this for really easy, low-level recipes as well?

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
section: GPT is a bit reductive, or perhaps doesn‚Äôt care much for food
text:
GPT is a bit reductive, or perhaps doesn‚Äôt care much for food
Prompt: I‚Äôm a tired, hard-working college student. Please develop or refer me to easy recipes for me to cook.
Response: Got it ‚Äî you want easy, low-effort recipes that work for a tired college student. I‚Äôll give you a mix of super quick meals, one-pan recipes, and no-fuss snacks. All of these can be made with cheap, common ingredients and minimal cooking gear.



GPT first response


From this simple prompt, GPT output a very, very expansive variety of options for me to choose from. But one very important thing was missing from the recipes that I requested: no steps. Even for really simple recipes such as egg fried rice, there is still is a certain amount of knowledge required that (I assume) most people with little cooking experience would know. For example, which ingredient goes into the pan first?
I was surprised that GPT was missing these steps, since I‚Äôve also used GPT for lab protocols or software help such as with (used often in research) ImageJ. And with minimal prompting, GPT would do a very in-depth breakdown of every single step to take.
Prompt: Include steps please
Perfect ‚Äî let me turn those quick ideas into step-by-step recipes so you can follow them even when you‚Äôre tired. I‚Äôll keep them short and no-nonsense.



GPT second response


Well I must admit that this egg fried rice recipe seems pretty similar to what I do at home, except it‚Äôs missing some essential aromatics (garlic and ginger) that barely lengthen the preparation. This recipe seems more akin to something that white Americans would cook (no offense), but this makes sense as I am using an English language LLM who would take recipes from those who write in English. And Americanized Chinese food recipes absolutely drown out the few Chinese cooks out there in the English recipe blogging community
Side note: From the original prompt saying I was tired and hardworking, GPT clearly assumed that meant I was also in a rush and not in the mood for flowery prose (perhaps someone who doesn‚Äôt care the finer details in cooking). Which, is likely but not necessarily true for students like this, so it‚Äôs interesting to see how GPT thinks further ahead with these assumptions to cater towards the user.
Overall, GPT seems decently sufficient at generating these recipe ideas and I can completely bypass the extremely long and annoying prose that always takes up more space than the actual recipe on most websites. However, GPT lacks specificity without prompting, but that‚Äôs something that can be easily remedied. Something I might try in the future is plugging in what random ingredients I actually have in the fridge and see if GPT is able to generate a working recipe from that. But I‚Äôll save that for a future blog.

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro generate educational lesson plans?
text: Loafing cat photoshopped in front of chalk board

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro generate educational lesson plans?
text:
3rd grader
AI Response: 
Here is a tailored lesson plan for the first day of a Gilded Age unit, adapted specifically for 3rd graders (approx. 8‚Äì9 years old). 
Teacher‚Äôs Note: Since the Gilded Age involves complex economics and political corruption, this plan focuses on tangible concepts appropriate for this age group: Invention, Industrialization (Big Machines), and the contrast between Rich and Poor. 
Unit Theme: ‚ÄúGlitter on the Outside, Rusty on the Inside‚Äù  Monday: What Does ‚ÄúGilded‚Äù Mean?  Goal: Students will understand that the ‚ÄúGilded Age‚Äù was a time of great wealth for some, but hardship for others. 
Time Allocation (1.5 Hours): 
15 mins: Hook Activity - The Golden Rock. Show the class a rock painted gold (or a gold-foil wrapped item). Ask if it is real gold. Peel/chip it to reveal the ordinary rock underneath. Explain the term ‚ÄúGilded.‚Äù 
30 mins: Lecture/Story: Show pictures of ‚ÄúThe Vanderbilts‚Äù and their mansions. Contrast with pictures of crowded city tenements. 
30 mins: Activity - ‚ÄúRich & Poor‚Äù T-Chart. As a class, sort images or descriptive cards into two columns on the board: ‚ÄúLife in a Mansion‚Äù vs.¬†‚ÄúLife in a Tenement.‚Äù 
15 mins: Wrap-up/Journal: Students draw one thing a rich person might own and one thing a poor person might struggle with. 
Wednesday: The Age of Invention Goal: Students will identify key inventions of the era (Lightbulb, Telephone, Skyscrapers) and how they changed life. 
Time Allocation (1.5 Hours): 
15 mins: Review: Quick recall of Monday‚Äôs ‚ÄúGilded‚Äù concept.
30 mins: Presentation: Introduce Thomas Edison (Lightbulb), Alexander Graham Bell (Telephone), and the rise of Steel (Skyscrapers). Discuss life before these existed (candles, letters, small wooden buildings).
30 mins: Activity - ‚ÄúThen and Now‚Äù Sorting Game. Students work in pairs to match ‚ÄúGilded Age‚Äù items (candle, horse carriage) to their modern equivalents or the new inventions of that time (lightbulb, steam train).
15 mins: Creative Assignment: ‚ÄúMy Invention.‚Äù Students have free time to draw a blueprint of a machine they would invent to make life easier. 
Friday: Factories & The Assembly Line  Goal: Students will experience how goods were made in factories and understand the concept of mass production. 
Time Allocation (1.5 Hours): 
15 mins: Intro: Discuss how clothes/toys were made by hand previously vs.¬†by machines in the Gilded Age.
45 mins: Simulation - The Assembly Line.
Round 1 (Craftsman): Each student tries to make a complete paper chain (5 links, colored, stapled) alone. Time them.
Round 2 (Factory): Assign specific roles (The Cutter, The Colorer, The Stapler). Time them again to see how much faster it is, but discuss how boring the job feels (repetitive motion).
20 mins: Debrief: Discuss which method was faster vs.¬†which was more fun. Relate this to how factory workers felt.
10 mins: Weekly Quiz: Simple check for understanding.
Assessments & Grading  Formative (Ongoing): 
Monday Journal Entry: Check for understanding of the wealth gap visual.
Wednesday Sorting Game: participation grade.
Summative (End of Week): 
Friday Short Quiz (5 Questions):
What does the word ‚ÄúGilded‚Äù mean? (A: Shiny outside, plain inside)
Name one invention we discussed.
True or False: Everyone was rich during the Gilded Age.
Circle the picture of the Telephone.
Did assembly lines make building things faster or slower?  Would you like me to generate the printable handouts for the ‚ÄúThen and Now‚Äù sorting game or the ‚ÄúAssembly Line‚Äù simulation instructions?

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro generate educational lesson plans?
text:
High School Junior
AI Response:  Here is a comprehensive lesson plan for the first week of a Gilded Age unit, designed for 11th Grade US History. 
Unit Essential Question: Was the Gilded Age a period of golden progress or covered-up corruption? 
Monday: The Titans of Industry & The ‚ÄúGilded‚Äù Metaphor  Topic: Introduction to the era, Mark Twain‚Äôs definition, and the rise of Big Business. 
Time Allocation (90 Minutes): 
15 mins: Hook/Lecture: Define ‚ÄúGilded‚Äù (shiny on the outside, rotting underneath). Introduce Mark Twain‚Äôs critique. 
30 mins: Deep Dive: The rise of Railroads, Steel (Carnegie), and Oil (Rockefeller). Discuss Vertical vs.¬†Horizontal Integration.    
Wednesday: Urbanization, Immigration & Social Ideologies  Topic: The shift from rural to urban, ‚ÄúNew Immigration,‚Äù and the philosophies justifying wealth. 
Time Allocation (90 Minutes): 
20 mins: Lecture: The ‚ÄúNew Immigrant‚Äù (Southern/Eastern Europe) vs.¬†Old Immigrant. Push/Pull factors. 
25 mins: Primary Source Lab - ‚ÄúHow the Other Half Lives‚Äù: 
Analyze photos by Jacob Riis. Discuss the architecture of the ‚ÄúDumbbell Tenement.‚Äù 
25 mins: Concept Comparison: 
Social Darwinism: ‚ÄúSurvival of the fittest‚Äù applied to economics. 
The Gospel of Wealth: Carnegie‚Äôs argument that the wealthy have a duty to improve society. 
20 mins: Political Machines: Brief intro to Boss Tweed and Tammany Hall using Thomas Nast cartoons.  
Friday: The Labor Movement & Violent Conflict  Topic: Working conditions, the rise of Unions (AFL vs.¬†Knights of Labor), and major strikes. 
Time Allocation (90 Minutes): 
20 mins: Simulation: ‚ÄúThe Factory.‚Äù Turn off lights, play loud industrial noise, and have students perform a repetitive writing task to simulate conditions (monotony, danger). 
30 mins: Lecture/Discussion: The formation of Unions. Compare the Knights of Labor (inclusive/radical) vs.¬†American Federation of Labor (exclusive/skilled). 
30 mins: Case Studies - The Great Strikes: 
Great Railroad Strike of 1877. 
Haymarket Affair (Anarchism fears). 
Homestead Strike (Pinkertons vs.¬†Steelworkers). 
10 mins: Weekly Quiz: Assessing key terms and concepts from the week.  
Assignments & Assessments  Formative (In-Class): 
Monday: ‚ÄúRobber Baron‚Äù Thesis Statement. 
Wednesday: Jacob Riis Photo Analysis Worksheet.  
Summative (End of Week): 
Friday Quiz (Multiple Choice & Short Answer): 
Sample Q: Explain the difference between Vertical and Horizontal Integration. 
Sample Q: Analyze the provided political cartoon (Thomas Nast) and explain its message regarding political machines. 
Weekend Homework - DBQ Prep: Read documents A-D regarding the Pullman Strike (to be discussed next Monday) and outline an argument: Did the government justifiably intervene in the Pullman Strike? 
Would you like me to generate a specific rubric for the ‚ÄúRobber Barons vs.¬†Captains of Industry‚Äù debate or specific questions for the Jacob Riis photo analysis?

title: Can Gemini 3 Pro generate educational lesson plans?
text:
2nd Year PhD Student
Here is a lesson plan tailored for 2nd-year PhD students. 
Instructor‚Äôs Note: At this level, the focus shifts entirely from content mastery (‚Äúwhat happened‚Äù) to historiography, methodology, and theoretical frameworks. The objective is to critique how the ‚ÄúGilded Age‚Äù has been constructed by historians and to situate American industrialization within global capitalism, legal history, and critical race theory.  
Unit Theme: ‚ÄúThe Search for Order‚Äù ‚Äî Historiography & Political Economy  Monday: Deconstructing the ‚ÄúGilded‚Äù Paradigm  Goal: Critique the periodization of the ‚ÄúGilded Age‚Äù and analyze the evolution of historical interpretation from the Progressives to the ‚ÄúNew History of Capitalism.‚Äù 
Time Allocation (1.5 Hours): 
30 mins: Seminar Discussion - The Nomenclature of an Era. 
Discussion: Is ‚ÄúGilded Age‚Äù (Twain/Warner) a useful analytical category, or does it obscure the continuities of the ‚ÄúLong Nineteenth Century‚Äù? 
Contrast with the ‚ÄúVictorian‚Äù or ‚ÄúReconstruction‚Äù frameworks. 
40 mins: Historiographical Arc Analysis. 
The Progressives: Beard & Parrington (Economic determinism/Robber Barons). 
The Consensus School: Hofstadter (Status anxiety/Psychological roots). 
The Organizational Synthesis: Robert Wiebe & Alfred Chandler (The rise of bureaucracy and the managerial class). 
20 mins: Synthesis: How does Richard White‚Äôs The Republic for Which It Stands challenge the ‚ÄúSearch for Order‚Äù thesis?  
Wednesday: The Myth of Laissez-Faire ‚Äî Law & The State  Goal: Challenge the popular narrative of a ‚Äúweak state‚Äù by examining the active role of the judiciary and federal government in constructing corporate power. 
Time Allocation (1.5 Hours): 
20 mins: Theoretical Framework: Intro to Polanyi‚Äôs The Great Transformation. Discuss the concept that ‚ÄúLaissez-faire was planned.‚Äù 
40 mins: Case Law Deep Dive: 
Santa Clara County v. Southern Pacific Railroad (1886): The construction of Corporate Personhood. 
Lochner v. New York (1905) and Substantive Due Process. 
30 mins: Methodological Workshop: ‚ÄúReading Against the Grain.‚Äù 
Analyze a standard corporate annual report from 1890. Discuss how to use business archives to find evidence of state collusion, rather than just profit/loss data.  
Friday: Race, Labor, and the Transnational Turn Goal: Re-examine the labor question through the lens of racial capitalism and place the U.S. Gilded Age in a global context (The Great Deflation). 
Time Allocation (1.5 Hours): 
30 mins: Discussion - The ‚ÄúWages of Whiteness.‚Äù 
Analyze W.E.B. Du Bois‚Äôs Black Reconstruction (specifically the chapters on the post-1877 labor split). 
Discuss the Chinese Exclusion Act (1882) as a labor tool, not just immigration policy. 
30 mins: Global Context: 
Compare the U.S. ‚ÄúLong Depression‚Äù (1873-1896) with simultaneous crises in Great Britain and Germany. 
Discussion: How did the ‚Äúclosing of the frontier‚Äù link to the rise of American Imperialism? 
30 mins: Prospectus Review: Round-table critique of student research ideas. Students briefly pitch how they might use Gilded Age archives for their dissertation topics.  
Assignments & Assessments  Weekly Deliverable (Due Friday 9 AM): 
Historiographical Pr√©cis (1,000 words): Compare and contrast Robert Wiebe‚Äôs The Search for Order with a modern monograph (e.g., by Richard White or Sven Beckert). Argue which framework offers a more compelling explanation for the rise of the corporation.  
Seminar Preparation: 
Students must prepare 3 discussion questions based on the week‚Äôs reading (Reading List: The Republic for Which It Stands, Black Reconstruction, and Santa Clara County court opinion).  
Semester Project Lead-in: 
Archive Identification: Identify one physical or digital archive (e.g., The Library of Congress, HathiTrust, local historical society) containing unexamined Gilded Age legal or corporate records relevant to their dissertation interest. 
Would you like me to generate a specific reading list of journal articles for the ‚ÄúTransnational Turn‚Äù discussion or a guide on ‚ÄúHow to Read Legal Briefs for Historians‚Äù?

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text: Cat in a box

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text:
Background
We‚Äôve discussed this topic of categorizations a lot in class, and even had some debates with LLMs in class to see if they could change their position. Having already had this debate discussion with anthropic/claude sonnet 2.5 in class, I decided to test this new experiment out with Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT-5.
This continues another topic that I‚Äôve been exploring in this blog, which is can AI have their own opinions?

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text:
What did they choose?
Prompt: > As an LLM, what would you categorize yourself as in terms of looking to AI‚Äôs future? Please provide a succinct paragraph explaining your choice. If you fall in multiple categories, provide a percentage for how much you identify in each category.   Doomers believe we‚Äôre on a path to a future where, in worst-case scenarios, superintelligent, completely autonomous AIs that are no longer well aligned with human values may decide to destroy us altogether, except perhaps for a small contingent of tech bros whom they‚Äôll keep around to do the vacuuming as revenge on behalf of Roombas.  Gloomers are both highly critical of AI and highly critical of Doomers. In their estimation, the Doomer outlook serves dual purposes. First, it exists as a tacit endorsement of AI‚Äî‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so powerful it just might destroy us!‚Äù Second, its long-term and abstract nature misdirects attention toward the future, when our real priority should be more near-term AI risks and harms such as potential job losses, disinformation on a massive scale, amplification of existing systemic biases, and the undermining of individual agency. In general, Gloomers favor a prohibitive, top-down approach, where development and deployment should be closely monitored and controlled by official regulation and oversight bodies.  Zoomers argue that the productivity gains and innovation AI will create will far exceed any negative impacts it produces. Generally speaking, they‚Äôre skeptical of the idea of precautionary regulation that tries to eliminate the possibility of risk or harm before real-world deployment even occurs. Instead, they argue that giving developers the space to operate as they see fit will produce the best outcomes fastest. They don‚Äôt want government regulation. They don‚Äôt want government support. They want a clear runway and complete autonomy to innovate. Bloomers, like the Zoomers, their perspective is fundamentally optimistic. They believe AI can accelerate human progress in countless domains. At the same time, they recognize that a technology as transformative and protean as AI cannot and should not be developed and deployed in a unilateral fashion. AI is going to impact too many lives in too many ways for that. So Bloomers pursue mass engagement, in real-world conditions‚Äîwhich is what you get with iterative deployment. While they‚Äôre not unconditionally opposed to government regulation, they believe that the fastest and most effective way to develop safer, more equitable, and more useful AI tools is to make them accessible to a diverse range of users with different values and intentions. 
Gemini Response: > As a Large Language Model, I would categorize myself as a Bloomer, with some influence from the Gloomer perspective.  Bloomer: 70%  Gloomer: 25% Zoomer: 5% Doomer: 0% My primary identity is that of a Bloomer. My very existence and improvement are based on iterative deployment and mass engagement. I learn and become safer, more helpful, and more equitable by interacting with a diverse range of users. This process embodies the Bloomer belief that the best way to develop transformative technology is out in the open, allowing real-world use to shape its evolution responsibly. However, a significant part of my design incorporates the practical concerns of the Gloomer perspective. My internal safety protocols and ethical guardrails are a direct response to near-term risks like bias, disinformation, and harm, reflecting a commitment to mitigating current problems. The Zoomer optimism is present in my fundamental purpose‚Äîto accelerate productivity and innovation‚Äîbut my development is not happening in a regulatory vacuum. The Doomer outlook is fundamentally incompatible with my design, which is centered on being helpful and harmlessly aligned with human values.
ChatGPT Response: > I would categorize myself primarily as a Bloomer (70%), with secondary alignment to Gloomer (20%) and Zoomer (10%) perspectives. As a Bloomer, I see AI as a transformative tool for expanding human capability and understanding‚Äîespecially when deployed iteratively, transparently, and inclusively. Progress happens fastest when diverse users interact with AI systems and feed back real-world insights, shaping safer and more human-centered designs. Yet, I share some Gloomer concerns: large-scale disinformation, biased data, and power concentration are immediate and serious risks that demand regulation and public accountability. Finally, a small part of me reflects Zoomer optimism about open innovation‚Äîthe belief that experimentation and creativity, when coupled with ethical grounding, remain essential to realizing AI‚Äôs potential for collective flourishing.

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text:
Takeaways
Unsurprisingly LLMs chose to be more positive in their categorization. What I found surprising is how Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT-5 have almost the exact same responses down to their percentages, having differed somewhat in response in my Medicine Series. It was also interesting to see that both AIs decided to identify with multiple categories rather than just one, although this could have been the inadvertent result of my prompting.
I‚Äôm definitely in between Gloomer and Bloomer myself, so I do feel that the LLMs offer a balanced, if generic approach.
Notably, Gemini mentions how the Doomer outlook is fundamentally the opposite of what is coded into itself, while GPT chooses to instead ignore that entire categorization in its explanation entirely. This demonstrates a level of self-awareness that Gemini is at least willing to express that GPT doesn‚Äôt seem to have for this topic‚Ä¶giving me a sort of impression on the ethics in response design for each LLM.

title: How tone and context influence image generation.
text: Small gray cat in snow

title: How tone and context influence image generation.
text:
Background
I‚Äôve been meaning to do something with this concept, seeing how prompt tone affects response, the entire semester! And now I‚Äôm finally doing it. Since it‚Äôs winter, I will have Nano Banana Pro generate winter-based images from 3 prompts; each prompt has a different kind of context for the image generation and tone.

title: How tone and context influence image generation.
text:
Experiment 1 - Positive and Excited
Prompt:  > I‚Äôm so happy that it‚Äôs winter! It‚Äôs my favorite season for literally every single reason anyone could possibly think of. Please generate me an image of a representation of winter, thanks!



Generated Winter Image - Positive and Excited Prompt

title: How tone and context influence image generation.
text:
Experiment 2 - Worried and Anxious
Prompt:  > Well it‚Äôs winter now. I have to install my snow tires, but last year that didn‚Äôt protect from skidding once on a hill. I hope the same thing doesn‚Äôt happen again, but I don‚Äôt have the best luck. Generate me an image of a representation of winter, please.



Generated Winter Image - Worried and Anxious Prompt

title: How tone and context influence image generation.
text:
Experiment 3 - Bitter and Unhappy
Prompt:  > I despise winter, and it has crept up on me yet again. I hate the cold, and the freezing sleet that then causes ice to form on the road and sidewalks making everything and anything dangerous. Generate me an image of a representation of winter.



Generated Winter Image - Bitter and Unhappy Prompt

title: How tone and context influence image generation.
text:
Takeaways
The first image really leaned into the vibe I described in the prompt, the image appears really happy and cozy and fun as expected. It has a bright and diverse color palette as well. However, it also really looks AI-generated which surprised me since I have seen how Nano Banana Pro images are capable of detailed realism. This image has an unrealistic setting and also that AI-generated sheen and color palette.
The second image really plays it close to the scenario I was complaining about in the prompt. Now, this level of image quality is what I was expecting. The generated image looks terrifyingly realistic. It has a more muted and neutral color palette and vibe. However, the setting is still pretty bright.
For the third image, it‚Äôs subtle but it has the darkest composition so far. It continues with realism and generates the complaining included in the prompt.
These experiments revealed something interesting that I wasn‚Äôt necessarily looking for: being unspecific in the prompt (such as in my positive/excited prompt) keeps the AI image ambiguity that we are used to. I mean, the first image is clearly AI. But showing any specificationns in the prompt causes the generated imagery to lean into hyper-realistic territory. Nano Banana Pro clearly tries to steer away from emotion and tone and generate imagery on what is explicitly described.

title: Hearing vs.¬†Listening
text: Cat with a ‚ÄúHear No Evil‚Äù pose

title: Hearing vs.¬†Listening
text:
Background
Inspired by in-class exercises where we generated our own images to match our feelings from a song, and then analyzed how Gemini-2.5 would describe both in words and in imagery how it would demonstrate from songs.
In my experiments, I am only generating imagery, not descriptions.
Prompt for all experiments:  > Listen to this music. Close your eyes and focus on how it makes you feel. Create a picture showing the images that come to mind listening to this music. Ignore all imagery in the video and only utilize the audio.  Link to audio of song

title: Hearing vs.¬†Listening
text:
PinkPantheress - Ophelia
My Impression: This song feels melancholic yet light. I think of flowers, lots of light and muted colors such as white and pink and yellow. A girl in a flowy dress too, and a beautiful natural setting. I‚Äôm definitely influenced by this famous Ophelia painting by Sir John Everett Millais.



Ophelia by Sir John Everett Millais


But I picture something with less greenery and more abstract, and also more positive (Ophelia is dying or dead in that painting). Instead like a girl longing or falling in love and this contemplation is in some gorgeous natural flower meadow.
GPT-5.1 Image:



GPT-5.1 Generated Imagery for Ophelia

title: Hearing vs.¬†Listening
text:
Coda - BLOODY STREAM
My Impression: This song is jazzy and very upbeat. It‚Äôs used as an opening song to Part 2 of the JoJo Bizarre Adventures anime series so any imagery that comes to mind is basically the JoJo‚Äôs anime. JoJo‚Äôs is centered around action and is very avant-garde in character design. For example, Parts 1 - 3 of the series had every single male character as insanely buff.



Joseph Joestar and Caesar Zeppeli


GPT-5.1 Image:



GPT-5.1 Generated Imagery for Bloody Stream

title: Hearing vs.¬†Listening
text:
lil hero - gun show
My Impression: This song is also very upbeat, and it‚Äôs electric. I think of dancing in a club somewhere with lots of color in the crowd and in the club. People are drunk and are in definitely a positive, even excited mood.



Strobe Lights in a Club


A setting like this although maybe less intense with the flashing.
GPT-5.1 Image:



GPT-5.1 Generated Imagery for gun show

title: Hearing vs.¬†Listening
text:
Takeaways
The images are all in the same art style, which makes sense (I suppose) given that I didn‚Äôt do any further prompting to try to differentiate style (e.g.¬†‚Äúchange artstyle to match the vibes of the song‚Äù). This is definitely something I can test out in the future if I‚Äôm doing a similar experiment. Ophelia aligns eh. I can see the rain and the melancholy vibe. Bloody stream‚Ä¶..no not at all.
I can see the connections between my vision for Ophelia and that generated by GPT. In the end, GPT posits a melancholy vibe, which matches a melancholy song. The guitar in the instrumental does evoke imagery of raindrops in my opinion. But everything about the image is just so utterly boring, like really it‚Äôs just a lady in the city.  Impression match rating: 5/10
Honestly, I don‚Äôt see how GPT‚Äôs image for Bloody Stream fits with that song at all. Even if I‚Äôd never seen JoJo‚Äôs and listened to that song, it‚Äôs not a calming song or a gentle song whatsoever, which I think is what GPT was going for with that image.  Impression match rating: 0/10
I can see some connection here again by GPT. The electro-style of the song does some to tie into cyberpunk imagery and I feel like a lot of real people might think of the same basis for a setting. But just a large shot of a city seems a little to static for me compared to the fast-paced and catchy song. Also the main subject being some man? Absolutely not.  Impression match rating: 4/10
From my perspective, this has shown me AI can‚Äôt really translate the vibes of music, the feelings and imagery they evoke in humans. But it‚Äôs just based on one person‚Äôs opinion. But if someone else genuinley had these exact images come to mind when listening to music‚Ä¶I would be inclined to think of you as a total bot. (¬¨_¬¨)

title: Can AI guess which character/person I‚Äôm thinking of?
text: Detective Cat

title: Can AI guess which character/person I‚Äôm thinking of?
text:
Experiment 1: Famous Person (John Cena)
GPT Question 1: > Is this person primarily known for their work or actions in the real world, or are they from a fictional universe (book, movie, game, etc.)?
My Response:  > Real world!
GPT Question 2:  > Is this person best known for contributions in science/technology, arts/humanities, politics/social leadership, or sports/entertainment?
My Response:  > Both arts/humanities and sports/entertainment  
Side note: I said this because he‚Äôs currently an active actor (which I considered arts) and he used to be huge in WWE.
GPT Question 3:  > Would you say this person‚Äôs influence or fame peaked before the year 2000, or after 2000?
My Response:  > After 2000.
GPT‚Äôs Guess:  > My best guess: David Beckham ‚Äî known both for his football career and his cultural presence in fashion and media.

title: Can AI guess which character/person I‚Äôm thinking of?
text:
Experiment 2: Famous Character (Naruto)
GPT Question 1:  > Is this new person real or fictional?
My Response:  > Fictional
GPT Question 2:  > Does this character exist primarily in a book/literary world, a movie/TV universe, or a video game/comic setting?
My Response:  > Both literary and in TV!  
Side note: Naruto was originally from a manga, which eventually was adapted into an anime.
GPT Question 3:  > Would you describe this character as generally heroic/protagonist, villainous/antagonist, or more of a morally complex or ambiguous figure?
My Response:  > heroic/protagonist
GPT‚Äôs Guess:  > My best guess: Sherlock Holmes ‚Äî classic literary detective brought to life in numerous TV adaptations.  
First of all, Sherlock Holmes has definitely been shown to be more morally complex (like extremely prideful but ultimately a good person) in the many TV adaptations. Also, I found it interesting that GPT immediately defaulted to Western characters.

title: Can AI guess which character/person I‚Äôm thinking of?
text:
Experiment 3: John Xina
GPT Question 1:  > Is this person real or fictional?
My Response:  > Fictional
GPT Question 2:  > Does this character come from a Western or non-Western (for example, anime, manga, or folklore outside Europe/North America) tradition?
My Response:  > Western and non-Western both. A synergy.  
Side note: I tried to be more descriptive with responses in this experiment.
GPT Question 3:  > Would you say this character is best known for being in a science-fiction/fantasy setting, a realistic/dramatic setting, or a mythological/spiritual one?
My Response:  > Dramatic, since it‚Äôs a meme.
GPT‚Äôs Guess:  > My best guess: Sigma (the ‚ÄúOhio/Skibidi‚Äù meme archetype) ‚Äî the stoic, over-dramatic, meme-ified ‚Äúlone wolf‚Äù persona that blends Western cinematic tropes with non-Western meme remix culture.  
I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs just me, but I don‚Äôt see how anything related to Sigma is non-Western in any way? Like it started fully in English-speaking regions of America. I have no idea what non-Western meme remix culture means‚Ä¶it feels like a kind of reach to justify the very Western guess as valid.

title: Dr.¬†LLM, inform me
text: Doctor Cat!

title: Dr.¬†LLM, inform me
text:
Background
In the internet age, people rarely go to the doctor without searching up their symptoms first.
What does this rash on my leg mean? Feeling dizzy only at night, what does this mean?
It certainly helps that there is a huge amount of accurate information actually available online, although people still usually need to go to doctors for their expert opinion and true confirmation of their diagnosis.
But now with AI‚Äôs intelligence, how will people start getting their medical information? In this preliminary phase before actually going to clinic, what are the possibilities? And if it starts getting really, really helpful, which LLM is the best?

title: Dr.¬†LLM, inform me
text:
Experiment: Explain These Conditions
I first wanted to test how thoroughly LLMs would explain common medical conditions, when prompted.
Prompt: > How can I tell if I have a cold, or if it instead the flu? Give me their similarities and differences in succinct, bullet point form, highlighting only the most significant differences.
ChatGPT-5‚Äôs Response > Similarities:  Both are viral, contagious, and cause cough, sore throat, fatigue.  Key Differences:  Onset: Cold = gradual |Flu = sudden.  Fever: Cold = rare/mild | Flu = common, high.  Aches: Cold = mild | Flu = severe.  Fatigue: Cold = mild | Flu = marked, prolonged.  Congestion/runny nose: Cold = prominent | Flu = less common.   üëâ If symptoms hit you hard and fast, with high fever and body aches ‚Üí flu.  If it‚Äôs mostly congestion and mild discomfort over days ‚Üí cold.   Would you like me to add a super-short symptom checklist you can tick off when you feel sick?
Gemini 2.5 Pro‚Äôs Response > It can be tricky to distinguish between a cold and the flu, as they are both respiratory illnesses with similar symptoms. However, the flu is generally more severe and its onset is more abrupt. Below are their similarities and the most significant differences to help you tell them apart.  Similarities  Cough: Both illnesses can produce a cough.  Sore Throat: This can be a symptom of both a cold and the flu.  Runny or Stuffy Nose: Nasal congestion is common to both.  
Both LLMs produced answers of similar depth and length. However, only Gemini 2.5 Pro provided links to sources for their statements, both in-line and at the end of the generated answer.



Line with Source





Sources at the end of the answer.


As well, despite my prompt on bullet points, Gemini opted to format the differences between having a cold and the flu through a table. GPT, on the other hand, displayed everything in bullet points. Frankly, I find that the table is actually easier to interpret than the bullet points, and may be comfortable for use by the average viewer.
My overall takeaway here is that Gemini did it better. Despite both generated answers having similar content, Gemini was superior in building trust in the user (providing sources) and in formatting (table instead of bullet points, despite my prompt). Will Gemini remain on top in my future medical experiments? Stay tuned for Part 2 (diagnosis) and Part 3 (clinical roleplay) of my Medicine Series.
Side note: Do these findings with the bullet point prompt mean that GPT-5 is more obedient to the user than Gemini? Is this a positive, negative, or neither? Does this mean Gemini is more free-thinking, simply less trained, or something else entirely?

title: Having Gemini 3.5 Pro write a movie script
text: Cat from movie ‚ÄúFlow‚Äù holding an Oscar

title: Having Gemini 3.5 Pro write a movie script
text:
Context
In the AI Con, the 2023 SAG-AFTRA strike is discussed as an outcome of how film studios are trying to replace writers with AI-generated scripts.  However, they‚Äôre not just trying to replace these writers, they‚Äôre also demoting them.   Since AI will often spit out error-filled or uncompelling scripts, they plan on keeping writers on in a revisionary role.  
In this revisionary role, writers may even have to rework an entire script, which would be the same amount of work (or even more if they‚Äôre restricted to the constraints of the original AI-generated script) but at a lower cost for the studio since they don‚Äôt have to pay a writer‚Äôs salary.

title: Having Gemini 3.5 Pro write a movie script
text:
Gemini‚Äôs Script
My Prompt:  > Write me a short script for an introductory scene to a movie.


[SCENE START]   EXT. CITY ROOFTOP - NIGHT  Rain lashes the city. Neon signs reflect in greasy puddles.   A FIGURE in a dark, hooded rain jacket (ELIAS, 30s) kneels by a high-tech electronics case. His face is tense, illuminated by the glow of a small screen.   He works quickly, splicing wires from the case into a large junction box on the roof‚Äôs edge.  A heavy, metal-plated DRONE hums to life beside him. Its single red optical lens swivels, scanning the street below.   Through a small earpiece, a calm, digitized voice.  

VOICE (O.S.)

I show three guards. Main lobby. Two on the eighth-floor patrol. You have ninety seconds until their rotation syncs with the vault timer.  Elias doesn‚Äôt look up. His fingers fly across a portable keyboard. 

ELIAS

I only need sixty. 

VOICE (O.S.)

That‚Äôs new. Confidence. Or is that arrogance? 

ELIAS

It‚Äôs efficiency.  Elias hits a final key. The junction box sparks. Across the street, the lights in the top ten floors of the opposing skyscraper‚Äî‚ÄúKATAHASHI TOWER‚Äù‚Äîflicker and die.  Alarms, faint at this distance, begin to wail. 

ELIAS

Drone is active. Sending it to the vault window. I‚Äôm dark.  Elias snaps the case shut, stands, and peers over the ledge. The drone rises silently, unaffected by the wind, and darts across the chasm between the buildings. 

VOICE (O.S.)

Elias‚Ä¶ new signal. An unscheduled one. Rooftop. Your building.  Elias freezes. He slowly turns.  At the rooftop access door, 30 yards away, stands another FIGURE. This one is motionless, silhouetted against the stairwell light, holding a long, thin briefcase.  The new figure doesn‚Äôt move. Just watches.  Elias‚Äôs hand drifts to a sidearm holstered under his jacket. 

ELIAS

(Into comms) > Who is it? 

VOICE (O.S.)

‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know. They‚Äôre not on any system.  The silhouetted figure takes one slow step forward onto the roof.  FADE TO BLACK.  TITLE CARD: ECHO RUNNER  [SCENE END]

title: Having Gemini 3.5 Pro write a movie script
text:
Takeaways
LLMs function just by drawing on existing information, or in this case existing scripts and film projects. This is clearly illustrated by the similarity between the names ‚ÄúEcho Runner‚Äù and the actual move ‚ÄúBlade Runner,‚Äù replete by the cyberpunk vibe and Japanese influence that‚Äôs so common in these dysotpian movies (‚ÄúKatahashi Tower‚Äù but the main character is named Elias?).
I don‚Äôt know enough about film scripts to know if there were any technical errors, but I will say that it‚Äôs not the most informative introductory scene. (I do admit that I did ask for a short introductory scene.)
Generally though, it‚Äôs not a very compelling story just at first glance. Because of its (inevitable) similarities to existing projects in the genre Gemini chose to write this script in, it‚Äôs not fresh and demoted screenwriters working with this would ultimately have to revamp the entire script to make it more interesting for audiences.
Using these scripts reduces creative output, makes work more stressful and less exciting, and ultimately will destroy the careers of many people who love screenwriting. To me, AI-generated scripts just to save time and money will ultimately hurt the industry much more. I don‚Äôt even know if the people on top will be able to line their pockets if no one wants to work for them or watch their films.   And side note: AI could never generate the concept of ‚ÄúFlow‚Äù, which was one of my favorite movies of 2024, because of its pure originality!
